Networks (RPL) Networks (RPL)
draft-tripathi-roll-rpl-simulation-08 draft-tripathi-roll-rpl-simulation-08
Abstract Abstract
This document presents a performance evaluation of the Routing This document presents a performance evaluation of the Routing
Protocol for Low power and Lossy Networks (RPL) for a small outdoor Protocol for Low power and Lossy Networks (RPL) for a small outdoor
deployment of sensor nodes and for a large scale smart meter network. deployment of sensor nodes and for a large scale smart meter network.
Detailed simulations are carried out to produce several routing Detailed simulations are carried out to produce several routing
performance metrics using these real-life deployment scenarios. performance metrics using these real-life deployment scenarios.
Please refer to the pdf version of this document, which includes Please refer to the pdf version of this document, which includes
several plots for the performance metrics not shown in the txt several plots for the performance metrics not shown in the txt
version. version.

CDF: Cumulative Distribution Function. CDF: Cumulative Distribution Function.
Expected Transmission Count (ETX Metric): The expected number of Expected Transmission Count (ETX Metric): The expected number of
transmissions to reach the next hop is determined as the inverse transmissions to reach the next hop is determined as the inverse
of the link PDR. Consequently, in every hop, if the link quality of the link PDR. Consequently, in every hop, if the link quality
(PDR) is high, the expected number of transmission to reach the (PDR) is high, the expected number of transmission to reach the
next hop may be as low as 1. However, if the PDR for the next hop may be as low as 1. However, if the PDR for the
particular link is low, multiple transmissions may be needed. particular link is low, multiple transmissions may be needed.

summation of the ETX value for each link on the route a packet summation of the ETX value for each link on the route a packet
takes towards the destination. takes towards the destination.

difference between the number of expected transmissions (ETX difference between the number of expected transmissions (ETX

following a route determined by RPL and a route determined by a following a route determined by RPL and a route determined by a

2. Introduction 2. Introduction
Designing a routing protocol for Low power and Lossy link Networks Designing a routing protocol for Low power and Lossy link Networks
(LLNs) imposes great challenges, mainly due to low data rates, high (LLNs) imposes great challenges, mainly due to low data rates, high
probability of packet delivery failure, and strict energy constraint probability of packet delivery failure, and strict energy constraint
in the nodes. The IETF ROLL Working Group took on this task and in the nodes. The IETF ROLL Working Group took on this task and
specified the Routing Protocol for Low power and Lossy Networks (RPL) specified the Routing Protocol for Low power and Lossy Networks (RPL)
in [RFC6550]. in [RFC6550].
RPL is designed to meet the core requirements specified in [RFC5826], RPL is designed to meet the core requirements specified in [RFC5826],
skipping to change at page 4, line 38 skipping to change at page 5, line 9
protocol behavior in highly stressful conditions, if and only if real protocol behavior in highly stressful conditions, if and only if real
life data are used. Simulation is particularly useful when life data are used. Simulation is particularly useful when
theoretical model assumptions may not be applicable to such networks theoretical model assumptions may not be applicable to such networks
and scenarios. In this document, real deployed network data traces and scenarios. In this document, real deployed network data traces
have been used to model link behaviors and network topologies. have been used to model link behaviors and network topologies.

[NS-TEST2].

All the simulation results presented in this document corroborate the All the simulation results presented in this document corroborate the
expected protocol behavior for the topologies and traffic model used expected protocol behavior for the topologies and traffic model used
in the study. For the particular discussed scenarios, the protocol in the study. For the particular discussed scenarios, the protocol
is shown to meet the desired delay and convergency requirements and is shown to meet the desired delay and convergency requirements and
to exhibit self-healing properties without external intervention, to exhibit self-healing properties without external intervention,
incurring negligible control overhead (only a small fraction of data incurring negligible control overhead (only a small fraction of data
traffic). RPL provided near optimum path quality for most of the traffic). RPL provided near optimum path quality for most of the
packets in the scenarios considered and is able to trade-off control packets in the scenarios considered and is able to trade-off control
overhead for path quality as per the application and device overhead for path quality as per the application and device
requirement through configurable parameters (such as decision on when requirement through configurable parameters (such as decision on when
to switch to new parent), and thus can trade-off routing stability to switch to new parent), and thus can trade-off routing stability
for control overhead as well. Finally, as per the requirement of for control overhead as well. Finally, as per the requirement of
urban LLN deployments, the protocol is shown to scale to larger urban LLN deployments, the protocol is shown to scale to larger
topologies (few thousand nodes), for the topologies considered in topologies (few thousand nodes), for the topologies considered in
this implementation. this implementation.
